posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked:
Title says it all.

I‚Äôm just an alum who is curious since questnav seems to bring a lot of great benefits but I don‚Äôt see a lot of teams using it outside of my old team and ninjaneers.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.custom_user_title: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: It was only released in the last off-season so didn‚Äôt have any competition testing. After we‚Äôve seen it‚Äôs quite good, we thought of buying a headset and trying it, but this season we‚Äôve finally got vision processing working so we‚Äôll probably not try it and do other projects in the next offseason.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: We‚Äôre not using it due to the novelty, (released right before this season) and because we don‚Äôt have the time to test and integrate it.  We‚Äôre looking into it for next season, but that‚Äôs more of a fun offseason project than a guarantee.  From what I‚Äôve seen, it seems to be very well done, but I haven‚Äôt used it so that doesn‚Äôt mean much.

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked:
Seems neat.

But it was unproven in competition and our team is small enough to not be able to take the risk in season to develop it.?

We still hadn‚Äôt fully mastered the tools we have available to us at the time of the season starting ( a stock of limelights from late last season )

Don‚Äôt get me wrong though. i love the idea of using something i can buy at walmart for half the cost of a limelight and has a ton of R&D put into it for a non FRC use. it‚Äôll never be ‚Äòunobtanium‚Äô

and (from memory only ) if it doesn‚Äôt require a co-processor (90% sure it doesn‚Äôt ) it‚Äôs one less thing to worry about as well.

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: We are still not sure how the starting position works, and how the headset knows where it is before match starts. I‚Äôm assuming it relies on other systems or beginning in the same spot, which is much less flexible then cameras. We could be mistaken. If it is based on starting position, then the accuracy is as good as the robot placement.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
Too much novelty. Novelty is schedule risk. Schedule risk derails readiness, which doesn‚Äôt meet team competitiveness goals.

If our team goals were more experiential than competitive, it could have swung the other direction.

The tech is super cool, going to play with it in the off-season.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: What is questnav

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
I mean on a real field it isn‚Äôt quite reliable yet. I‚Äôve seen data from questnav logged from an event this past weekend.

I‚Äôm willing to try some new things, but quest nav was outside of my comfort zone.

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked: It‚Äôs a new piece of software that allows the robot to find where it is on the field using the location tracking on a meta quest 3 or 3a.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked: Works better than limelight, costs less than limelight. The only ‚Äúunproven‚Äù tech is the thing in between the insanely advanced camera array and IMUs, and the Rio. Still not for the faint of heart.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
It‚Äôs not my data to share.

The logs I saw were from 4451‚Äôs robot. 4451 makes their entire codebase public and I was told the logs would be uploaded/shared after this weekend so I assume that information will be available soon.

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked:
EKM_319:

and (from memory only ) if it doesn‚Äôt require a co-processor (90% sure it doesn‚Äôt ) it‚Äôs one less thing to worry about as well.

Saying it doesn‚Äôt require a coprocessor isn‚Äôt really accurate. The Quest itself is the coprocessor along with housing the sensors used for tracking similar to say a limelight.

posts.name: Ege Saygƒ±lƒ±
posts.cooked: If I was a rookie team not invested into multiple limelights, I would definitely explore questnav for my team. If something is not a win condition level game changer(you can already achieve what you want vision wise with LL ), the adoption will be slow IMO.

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: We will probably use it next year if all goes well and we can figure out how the starting position finding works. It will change our workflow. Hopefully someone can make a smaller case for it.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: From talking to 4451, they logged the questnav data but used their 4-5 PV cameras only for localization as a trial run. Apparently the rotation is perfect but there is a few things they have to work out.

posts.name: Matt Boehm
posts.cooked: seems like a packaging nightmare to me

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
We have students who are really enthusiastic about trying it out and getting it to work. Definitely not a mentor led effort, lol, but certainly want to support students who want to stand out.

We wanted something that could help us overcome pose-reliability issues with respect to wheel-skid and be able to better track path-following. If this hadn‚Äôt come out, we might have pursued that similar to how Orbit does it as a way to innovate.

We did some early tests on reliability and robustness that met our criteria for sticking with it.

The team was supportive of taking a chance of something innovative that might lead to longer term success and that would help us stand out in the crowd.

We expected to be able to fallback on raw driving ability or simpler auto techniques if we couldn‚Äôt translate practice field success to in-match success.

posts.name: Owen Busler
posts.cooked: 8513 had a discussion about it when we saw the release. We worked a lot on our OrangePi/Arducam/PhotonVision setup in the offseason and decided that based off the april tag positions on the field we would decide if we needed QuestNav. When the game was released we were very happy with the tags on the field so we stuck with what we were more comfortable with. If the tags had been sparce it would have been a different discussion.
